openconnector

Class Filter

  • java.lang.Object
    • openconnector.Filter

  • public class Filter
extends java.lang.Object
    A Filter is a representation of criteria that can be used to search for objects. This model is intentionally simplified and does not support more sophisticated searches such as nested composites (for example - (a && b) || (c && d)). Typical usage involves creating a filter (either an AND or OR) and adding criteria to it. This filter model can later be turned into filters that can be used on resources (for example - an LDAP search string or JDBC where clause) or used to programmatically match objects. For example, to search for administrative users, you might use the following code. 

      Filter f = new Filter(Conjunct.OR);
  f.add("username", Operator.EQ, "root");
  f.add("username", Operator.STARTS_WITH, "adm_");
  f.add("username", Operator.EQ, "adm_notReallyAnAdmin", true);

      • getFilters

        public java.util.List<Filter> getFilters()
        Returns:
        the filters that represent the criteria that was added using the add methods. These will have a property, operate, value, and negate, but not a conjunct or sub-filters.

      • getConjunct

        public Filter.Conjunct getConjunct()
        Returns:
        the conjunct for this filter.

      • getProperty

        public java.lang.String getProperty()
        Returns:
        the property this filter is comparing against. This will return null unless called on a filter returned by getFilters().

      • getOp

        public Filter.Operator getOp()
        Returns:
        the operator this filter is using. This will return null unless called on a filter returned by getFilters().

      • getValue

        public java.lang.Object getValue()
        Returns:
        the value this filter is comparing the specified property against. This will return null unless called on a filter returned by getFilters().

      • isNegate

        public boolean isNegate()
        Returns:
        whether the operator is negated for this filter. This will always return false unless called on a filter returned by getFilters().
